thread.title: Modern cyborgs, just people with implanted devices living longer and better

author: Jill Margo
title: Modern cyborgs, just people with implanted devices living longer and better
text:
Men in the study felt biosensors might be used as a long-term warning system, alerting doctors when a cancer might have returned and potentially delivering drug therapy. supplied Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Jill Margo Men seem surprisingly open to the idea of having cancer-detecting biosensors implanted in their bodies, according to a report in Science as Culture.
One day such sensors could hopefully aid in the treatment or repair of tissue and organs without external human direction or control.
The report says sensors would bring them another step closer to becoming cyborgs, hypothetical people with mechanical elements built into their bodies that extend their physical abilities extended beyond human limitations.
Since the original cyborg was described in the early 1960s, science and technology have made giant leaps in creating 'everyday cyborgs' which, unlike those in science fiction, are real people who just happen to live with sophisticated devices that keep them functional and, in some cases, alive.
In the report entitled 'Cyborgs in the Everyday: Masculinity and Biosensing Prostate Cancer 'the authors portray a new version of cyborg that goes beyond the monster stereotype.
They argue biosensors are the key devices that differentiate a cyborg from a human sensing when cancer tumours, present in organs such as the prostate, will be most vulnerable to radiotherapy.
Their interviews with a dozen men recovering from prostate cancer revealed surprisingly positive and open views.
The men felt biosensors might be used as a long-term warning system, alerting doctors when a cancer might have returned and potentially delivering drug therapy.
 In their view, possible malfunctioning of the device was a risk worth taking as it was better to be cyborg than a 'leaker and a bleeder', a crude and somewhat offensive term referring to damage that could be caused by prostate cancer.
The interviews suggested having cancer increased men's willingness to try anything, making the modern cyborg just an ill and vulnerable man prepared to fight for his life with an implanted device.
